exam_system: Prefers multiple-choice questions.
Prefers mostly problem-solving, proofs, or applying new ideas based on previous knowledge.
Prefers mostly proofs, especially related to physical theories, and sometimes includes multiple-choice questions.
Prefers multiple-choice questions, fill-in-the-blanks, and solving problems based on formulas.
Prefers mostly multiple-choice questions.
Prefers definitions and questions that test the validity of chemical equations.
Prefers statistical problem-solving, proofs, and definitions.
Prefers a lot of mathematical problem-solving and mathematical proofs based on what has been studied.
Prefers mostly proofs, with some mathematical problem-solving.
Prefers mostly proofs, with some mathematical problem-solving.
Prefers practical questions to test the student's understanding of terminology by giving code with or without errors and asking the student to fix or analyze them.
Always prefers deep thinking questions, where students must innovate. He does not stick to one format but applies algorithms or ideas in new, unexpected ways.
Prefers multiple-choice questions, definitions, algorithm writing, or fill-in-the-blanks â€” not fixed, but these are examples.
Prefers essay questions, definitions, problem-solving in some subjects, and applying algorithms to examples.
Sometimes prefers multiple-choice, sometimes problem-solving, and sometimes algorithm applications.
Prefers multiple-choice questions, true/false, fill-in-the-blanks, and occasionally essay questions but to a lesser extent.
Relies heavily on theory. Most of his questions are large essay-style questions that require detailed writing.
Sometimes prefers multiple-choice questions, prefers definitions and algorithm writing, and occasionally includes theoretical questions but not extensively.
Prefers a lot of mathematical problem-solving and mathematical proofs based on what has been studied.
Always prefers deep thinking questions, encouraging students to innovate. He avoids fixed formats and prefers applying ideas in new contexts.
Prefers multiple-choice questions, sometimes definitions, and also essay questions.
Prefers multiple-choice questions.
Relies heavily on theory. Most questions are large essay-style or problem-solving tasks that require implementation.
